text: as the russian invasion intensifies in
ukraine more than two million refugees
have now fled the country according to
the united nations ukrainian officials
say humanitarian corridors have now
opened to evacuate civilians from five
key cities so let's take a closer look
now at russia's proposed evacuation
routes they've been dismissed by ukraine
four of the suggested safe corridors go
to the east to russia or to belarus the
other two routes take those fleeing
further into ukraine
and these are pictures of civilians
fleeing the northeastern city of sumi an
airstrike there we understand has killed
at least 21 people
president zielinski saying a convoy has
been sent towards the southern port city
of mariopol to rescue civilians who've
been living without running water or
power for almost a week
let's take you straight to levers now in
western ukraine we can join my colleague
who is there yalda hakeem yalda
lucy thank you and we're almost two
weeks into this conflict and two weeks
of
absolute desperation for the civilians
of this country the number of civilians
being killed continues to rise you
mentioned there
sue me in the northeast of the country
overnight we've heard dozens of
civilians being killed they're including
children there are other parts of this
country like in the south mariopol where
people are desperately trying to
evacuate but those humanitarian
corridors have not yet uh been set up
and we've also heard the defiance of
president zielinski he's continued to
come out give addresses day in day out
and yesterday we saw him come out of his
office to say he's not afraid and that
he will continue to fight sean dilley
has the latest
in large parts of ukraine the
bombardment has been relentless
civilians hoping to escape the danger
have sought whatever shelter they can as
russian shelling has prevented their
escape
many are hanging their hopes on a new
agreement between russia and ukraine to
create a new humanitarian corridor which
is now in place in the northeast city of
sumi where nine people reportedly died
yesterday
the ceasefire which is planned to last
until 9 pm local time will mean
civilians will be able to travel
kilometers south to poltava
ukraine's president though says he's
going nowhere
right to life for everyone
that
is what we are fighting for in ukraine
later president vladimir zolensky will
plead directly to uk mps at his request
in an historic first ukraine's head of
state will be hosted inside the main
commons chamber by video link he's
expected to ask uk lawmakers to do more
to help as the un believes the number of
those fleeing the embattled country will
hit 2 million today or tomorrow
so far the uk government says it's
granted visas to 300 refugees but its
defense minister says the process needs
to be sped up
fundamentally the overall scheme is
going to produce hundreds of thousands
of ukrainian in the united kingdom and i
think that is is a good thing to do it's
not the case that we're only allowing
300 people in it is the case that the
system has not been quick enough
but while the muzzle cracks and shelling
have temporarily stopped in some areas
the economic war rages ibm is the latest
tech giant to pull out of russia and a
new law to make it easier to sanction
oligarchs has passed its first stage in
the uk parliament last night
meanwhile the united states says it's
exploring a potential ban on russian oil
but russia says it would consider
closing its gas pipe to germany in
response this however is an unlikely
scenario with germany and the
netherlands rejecting the idea
today's agreement between the two
countries to help more civilians escape
through humanitarian corridors will
surely be seen as a positive move but
the international community is holding
its breath for a way forward as ukraine
and russia meet for a fourth round of
peace talks sean dilley bbc news
